title: How long would it take for my chapter 13 to be filed? what documents do I provide and how do they determine my payments
question: I am in debt from credit cards and payday lenders and taxes. I work and make around 5k a month before tax. I’m already starting to get sued. I don’t own anything and have a car that’s financed.
answers: A chapter 13 bankruptcy is very complex. There are many layers of rules to follow and the amount of preparation and thoroughness of that preparation can make all the difference between a successful chapter 13 case and a dismissed chapter 13 case. I strongly suggest you hire a bankruptcy attorney to help you prepare your bankruptcy case and represent you during your bankruptcy case. Typically, there is much more to a chapter 13 bankruptcy than just the petition packet. You can find many excellent bankruptcy attorneys here on AVVO.

Filing a chapter 13 can happen in two ways, (1) either a complete filing of all petition schedules and forms documents altogether or (2) an emergency filing where critical documents are filed including your voluntary petition, complete list of creditors, etc. and with all remaining documents required to be fined within 14 days of your filing date.

In an emergency filing scenario, depending on the law firm you enlist to help you, it should take no longer than 24-48 hours to file an emergency case (possibly shorter). If filing your complete set of petition schedules and forms, anticipate longer time for preparation and review and finalization before ready to file ... perhaps 5-7+ days.

Also, be prepared to take your required credit counseling course to receive your pre-bankruptcy counseling certificate which must also be filed with your initial set of documents. Your social security number declaration will also be needed at the initial filing, whether emergency or complete petition.

If you are serious about this course with chapter 13 Bankruptcy, you would be wisest to contact a few experienced bankruptcy lawyers as soon as possible to learn more about what you will need for them to help prepare your case.

Best of luck

Meet with a qualified Bankruptcy Attorney right away to determine which chapter offers the best remedies for you. You state you owe taxes, be sure and request a consultation with an attorney who is knowledgeable about discharging taxes in bankruptcy. Your case can be filed fairly quickly, your attorney will need documents that support your income and expenses, paychecks, credit report, federal and state tax returns, monthly statements and you will need to take a credit counseling class (usually takes about 1.5 hours) Many of the attorneys here offer free consultations.

I must tell you that according to US Trustee statistics, virtually all Chapter `2 cases filed by non-attorneys are dismissed for failure to follow the sometimes arcane sounding local Rules and other policies. If it were easy, no one would ever employ a lawyer. Chapter 13 cases allow you to pay some or most of your attorney fees through the monthly Plan payments. As said by other attorneys, it may be preferable to file a Chapter 7 and get a fresh start on your finances. Look at the client/peer reviews of the Avvo Bankruptcy lawyers until you find several with excellent review. Call several to discuss your specific concerns. If you don't get a prompt call back, go to the next one on your list. You will be surprised how much help is available to you if you ask for it. Sometimes it is possible to handle everything by email, fax, phone and regular mail so the location of the lawyer's office is not really a factor in who you decide on. If this response was helpful, please leave your feedback on Avvo. Good luck to you.

That's actually a rather complex question . Your case can generally be e-filed so that the actual filing can occur same day, provided you have completed the required credit counseling. It may, however, be better to hold off filing as taxes and secured debts such as an auto loan can receive a lesser treatment if certain time frames have run before filing. The amount you pay on a monthly basis depends upon the type of debt (unsecured, secured, auto loan, taxes, etc.) and the amount of your monthly disposable income. You should sit down with an experienced bankruptcy attorney to go over your debts and your options and determine which is best for you and, if you do file a bankruptcy, when the best time to file would be.

I agree that you want to make sure first that you do not qualify for chapter 7. If you qualify then you can wipe out all of your debt without having to pay any of it back. If your income disqualifies you from chapter 7 then chapter 13 could be an option. Your payments would be determined based on the discretionary income you have left at the end of the month once median household expenses are taken into account and any payments you make on secured property, such as your vehicle. It is best to consult with an experienced bankruptcy attorney first. They will guide you on which chapter is best for you and what documents are necessary. Hope this helps.

First of all, you need to be certain that a Chapter 13 is necessary. You may qualify for a Chapter 7. The Means Test is complicated, and it sounds as if you have checked it out. Trust me, you need an immediate Bankruptcy Attorney consultation from a well-qualified, highly reviewed AVVO attorney. You may be able to squeeze into a Chapter 7, if you are otherwise qualified.
To answer your question, most of us can file the same day we are paid the full retainer necessary, but that is not the preferred approach. Chapter 13 deserves more attention to detail. However, we can stop the lawsuit in its tracks! Hope you find an excellent, local attorney ASAP right here on AVVO, "Find an Attorney".
